Ti s a small fishing town on the south fide of the island of Martha’s Vineyard, 9 miles from Chilmark, and 97 from Boston. The township was incorporated in 1671, and contains 1142 inhabitants. It is in Duke’s county, Massachusetts, and in 1796 the easterly part was incorporated into a separate township.

Tisc a village of Ouenca, and department of Alaniis, in Quito, in SouthAmerica, which was entirely destroyed by an earthquake, but the inhabitants escaped, and removed to a safer situation. The marks of this dreadful convulsion of nature are still visible.
an island of 8. America, in the South Pacific Ocean, near the coast of Peru.

or Chucuito, a lake of Charcas, in Peru ; and is the largest of all the known lakes in 8. America. It is of an oval figure, with an inclination ! from N. W. to S. E. and about 80 leagues in circuit. The water is, in some parts, 70 or 80 fathoms deep. Ten or twelve large, belides a greater number of smaller streams fall into it. The water of this lake, though neither salt nor brackiih,

brackiih, is muddy, and has something ib nauseous in it's taste, as not to be drank. One of the moil splendid temples in the empire was erected on an island in this lake, by the Yucas. The Indians, on seeing the violent rapacity oí the Spaniards, are thought to have thrown the immense collection of riches in the temple, into this lake. But these valuable effects were thrown into another lake, in the valley of Orcos, 6 leagues S. of Cusco, in water 2.3 or 24 fathoms deep. Towards the S. part of Titicaca Lake, the banks approach one another, so as to forro a kind of bay, terminating in a river, called El Desaguadero, or the drain ; and afterwards forms the Lake of Paria, which has no visible outlet. Over the river El Desaguadero still remains the bridge of ruihes, invented by Capac-Yupanqui, the fifth Ynca, for transporting his army to the other fide, in order to conquer the provinces of Collafuyo. The Desaguadero is here between 80 and 100 yards in breadth, flowing with a very impetuous current, under a smooth, and, as it were, sleeping surface. The Ynca, to overcome this difficulty, ordered 4 very large cables to be made of a kind of grafs, which covers the lofty heaths and mountains of that country, anti by the Indians called Lchu: so that these cables were the foundation os' the whole structure. Two of these being laid across tire water, fascines of dry j une ira, and totora, two species of rushes, were fastened together, and laid across the cables. On this again the two other cables were laid, and covered with similar fascines securely fastened on, but of a smaller size than the first, and arranged ib as to form a level surface. And by this means the Ynca procured a safe passage for his army. This bridge of rushes, which is about five yards broad, and one yard and a half above the surface of the water, is carefully repaired, or rebuilt, every fix months by the neighbouring provinces, in pursuance of a law made by that Ynca; and since often confirmed by the kings of Spain, on account of its vast use, it being the channel of intercourse between those provinces on each side the Desaguadero.
a township of Rhode-Isl¡tnd, in Newport co. having the eastern Passage and part of Mount Hope Bav on the W. and N. W. the State of Massachusetts on the N. and E. and Little
Compton township on the south. It contains 2,453 inhabitants, including 25 slaves. It is about 13 miles N. N. E. of Newport.

a river in the N. W. part of S. America, 600 miles from New-Spain. In a journey made thus far, in 1606, the Spaniards found some large edifices, and met with some Indians who spoke the Mexican language, and who told them, that a few days journey from that river, towards the N. was the kingdom of folian, and many other inhabited places whence the Mexicans migrated. It is, indeed, confirmed by Mr. Stewart, in his late travels, that there are civilized Indians in the interior parts of America. Beyond the Missouri, he met with powerful nations who were courteous and hospitable, and appeared to be a polished and civilized people, having regularly built towns, and enjoying a state of society not far removed from the European ; and indeed to be perfectly equal wanted only iron and steel.
or Los Angelos , a province of New-Spain. See Angelos.
TOA, one of the two rivers, Bajamond being the other, which empty into the harbour or Porto Rico, in the island of that name in the West-indies.
T OAHOUTU, one of the two small islands to the N. eastward of the S. end of Otaha Island, one of the Society Islands, in the South Pacific Ocean.
ToAMENSINti, two townffiips of Pennsylvania ; the one in Montgomery co. the other in that of Northampton.

an island in the West-Indies, which, when in the hands of the Dutch, was called Nevj Fa Id: eren, is about 10 leagues to the N. of Trinidad, and 40 S. ot Barbadoes. Its length is about 32 miles, but its breadth only about 12, and its circumference about 80 miles. The climate is not so hot as might be expected so near the equator; and it is said that it lies out of the course of those hurricanes that have sometimes proved so fatal to the other West-India Islands. It has a fruitful foil, capable of producing sugar, and indeed every thing else that raised in the WestIndia Islands, with the addition (if we may believe the Dutch) of the cinnamon, nutmeg, and gum copal. It is well watered with numerous springs ; and its bays and rivers are so disposed as to be very commodious for all kinds of shipping. The value and import

anee of this island, appears from the extentive and formidable armaments lent thither in support of their different claims. It seems to have been chiefly pofleiTed by the Dutch, who defended their pretensions against both England and France, with the molt obstinate perseverance. By the treaty of Aix la Chapelle, in 1748, it was declared neutral ; though by the treaty of 176;,, it was yielded up to Great-Britain ; but in June, 1781, it was taken by the French, and ceded to them by the treaty of 1783 ; and captured by the Britiin in 1793. N. lat. n 16, W. long. 60 30.
Island,, Little, near the N. E. extremity of Tobago Island, in the Welt-Indies. It is about two miles long, and one broad.

Creek , an caftern branch of Alleghany river, in Pennsylvania : its southern head water is called Little Toby’s Creek. It runs about 35 miles in a W. 8. W. and W. course, and enters the Alleghany about 20 miles below Fort Franklin. It is deep enough for batteaux for a considerable way up, thence by a short portage to the W. branch of Suft|uebannah, by which a good communication is formed between Ohio, and the eaitern parts of Pennsylvania.
a city of Terra Firma, and in New Granada.
Creek, a water of Oakmulgee river, in Georgia.

a county of Connecticut, bounded N. by the State of Massachusetts, S. by New-Loodon co. E. by Windham, and W. by Hartford co. It is subdivided into 9 townslaips, and contains 13,106 inhabitants, including 47 slaves. A great proportion of the county is hilly, but the foil is generally strong and good for grazing.

the chief town of the above county, was incorporated in 1713, and is about 18 miles N. E. of Hartford. It has a Congregational church, courthouse, gaol, and 20 or 30 houses, compactly built, in the centre of the town.
a town of Terra Firma, 8. America, with a harbour on a bay of the N. Sea. The famous balsam of the fame name comes from this place ; 114 miles S. W. of Carthagena. N. lat. 9 36, W. long. 75 22.
a large river of Popayan, and Terra Firma, S. America, about 9

miles N. E. of Galla Isle. About a league and a half within the river is anIndian town of the lame name, and but small, the inhabitants of which common» ly supply small veslcls with provisions, when they put in here for refrelhment.
Island, on the cast coast of Patagonia, is 24 miles N. E. of Seal’s Bay.
River, on the coast of Peru, is between the port of Hilo and the rive r of Xuly or Chuly. There is anchorage against this river in 20 fathoms, and clean ground. Lat. 17 50 8.

River, is the dividing line between the Creeks and Chacta ws. Above the junction of Alabama and Mobile rivers, the latter is called the Tombigbee river, from the fort of Tombigbee, situated on the west fide of it, about 96 miles above the town of Mobile. The lburce of this river is reckoned to be 40 leagues higher up, in the country of the Chickaiaws. The fort of Tombigbee was captured by the Bvitiib, but abandoned by them in 1767. The river is navigable for sloops and schooners about 35 leagues above the town of Mobile: 130 American families are fettled on this river, that have been Spanish subjects lince 1783.

a jurisdiction in the archbishopric of La Plata in Peru. It begins about 18 leagues 8. E. from the city of Plata ; on its eastern confines dwell a nation of wild Indians, called Chiriguanos. It abounds with wine, sugar and cattle.

a lake of N. America, which fends its waters south-eastward through Ottawas river, into Lake St. Francis in St. Lawrence river. The line which separates Upper from Lower Canada, runs up to this lake by a line drawn due north, until it strikes the boundary line of Hudson’s Bay, or NewBritain.
á village of Pennsylvania, in Mifflin co. containing about a dozen houses. It is 22 miles Irotn Lewistown.
Creek, in New-Jersey, which separates the towns of Dover and Shrewsbury.

a river at the bottom of the Gulf of Campeachy, in the S. W. part of the Gulf of Mexico ; miles due west of St. Annes, and 24 Past of Guafickwalp. It is navigable for barges a«d other veil; is of from co to 60 tons.

the name of a creek and Indian town, in the north-western part of New-York. The creek runs a westward course and enters Niagara river opposite Grand Island, 8 miles N. of Fort Erie. It runs about 40 miles, and is navigable 28 miles from its mouth. The town stands on its S. side, 18 miles from Niagara river. Also the Indian name of Fishing Bay, on Lake Ontario.

one of the Friendly Islands, in the S. Pacific Ocean, about 60 miles in circuit, but rather oblong, and widest at the E. end. It has a rocky coast, except to the N. side, which is full of shoals and islands, and the shore is low and sandy. It furnilhes the best harbour or anchorage to be found in these islands. The island is all laid out in plantations, between which are roads and lanes for travelling, drawn in a very judicious manner for opening an easy communication from one part of the island to another. 8. lat. 219, W. long. 174 46. Variation of the needle, in 1777, was 9 53 E.

an island at the mouth of Lake D’Urfe, at the eastern extremity of Lake Ontario, is within the Britislx territories ; ix miles N. E. of Point au GoelanSj and 12 W. of Grand Island, having several isles between it and the latter.
or Tonty, a river which empties through the N. sliore of Lake Erie ; 22 miles W. by N. of Riviere a la Barbae.
Cape, on the coast of Chili, in 8. America, 15 leagues to the N. of Guasca, and in lat. 27 30 8.
one of the Society Islands, in the 8. Pacific Ocean, not more than j or 6 miles across in any part. 8. lat. 23 25, W. long. 149 23.
an Indian village on the N. W. coast of N. America, of considerable importance in the furtrade ; situated on a point of land between two deep founds. N. lat. 532, W. long. 131 30.

Too roocH, a small low island in Nootka Sound, on the N. W. coast of North-America, on the eastern side of which is a considerable Indian village ; the inhabitants of which wear a garment apparently composed of wool and hair, mostly white, well fabricated, and probably by themselves.
of New-Biscay province in Mexico# North-America; yet most of the neighbouring parts are pleasant, abounding with all manner of provisions.
a township of Maslachufetts, Eslex co. containing 780 inhabitants. It is 8 miles westerly of Ipswich, and 39 N. by E. of Boston.
a township of Vermont, in Orange co. west of Newbury, adjoining. It is watered by slime branches of Wait’s river, and contains 162 inhabitants.

a township of the District of Maine, in Lincoln co. 32 miles in circumference, and more than 25 miles is washed by water. It is bounded on the N. W. by Little river ; N. by Bowdoin and Bowdoinham; E. by Cathance and Merry Meeting Bay ; 8. and 8. W. by Amarifcoggin river, which separates it from Brunlwick in Cumberland county. The inhabitants amount to 82Ó fouls, and they live in such easy circumstances, that none have ever been ib poor as to solicit help from the parish. It was incorporated in 1764. A few English attempted to settle here in the end of the last, or beginning of the present century. These were cut off by the natives. Some families ventured to settle in this hazardous situation in 1730 ; from which period, until the peace of 1763, the inhabitants never felt wholly secure from the natives. It is 3 7 miles S. by W. of Hailowell, and 156 N. by E. of Boston; and is nearly in lat. 44 N. and long. 70 W.
a town on the eastern coast of Nova-Scotia; 22 miles 8. W. of Roaring Bull Island, and 100 N. E. of Halifax.
a village on the south side of the south peninsula oí the island of St. Domingo ; 3 leagues N. W. of At ache Island.

Cape, on the W. side of the Straits of Northumberland, or Sound, between the island of St. John’s and the E. coast of Nova-Scotia, is the N. point of the entrance to Bay Vert. It is due west from Governor’s Island, on the S. E. coast of the island of St. John’s. In some maps this point is called Cape Storm.
a British settlement on the north-western bank of Lake Ontario, 53 miles N. by W. of Fort Niagara. N. kt. 44 i, W. long. 79 xo.
Tos. RiNGTON, or Bedford's Bay , on

the southern coast of Nova-Scotia, and its entrance is at America Point, about 3 miles N. of the town of Halifax. It has from 10 to 13 fathoms at its mouth, but the bay is almost circular, and has from 14 to 50 fathoms water in it. A prodigious sea sets into it in winter.
a township of Connecticut, in Litchfield co. 8 miles N. of Litchfield.

TORTOisES,//*/tr't*r o/j lies 10 miles above a lake 20 miles long, and 8 or 10 broad, which is formed by the Miffisippi in Louisiana and Florida. It is a large fine river, which runs into the country a good way to the N. E. and is navigable 40 miles by the largest boats.

an island on the N. fide of the island of St. Domingo, towards the N. W. part, about 9 leagues long from E. to W. and 2 broad. The W. end is nearly 6 leagues from the head of the bay of Moustique. The freebooters and buccaniers drove the Spaniards from this island in 1632 ; in 1638, the Spaniards massacred all the French colony ; and in 1639, the buccaniers retook Tortue. In 1676, the French took poffeilion of it again.

Dry, shoals to the westward, a little southerly from Cape Florida, or the 8. Point of Florida, in SouthAmerica. They are 134 leagues from the bar of Pensacola, and in lat. 24 32 N. and long. 83 40 W. They consist of 10 small islands or keys, and extend E. N. E. and W. 8. W. 10 or 11 miles; most of them are covered with bushes, rind may be seen at the distance of four leagues. The south-west key is one of the smallest, but the most material tobe known, is in lat. 24 32 N- and long. 83 40 W. From the 8. W. part of this key, a reef of coral rocks extends about a quarter of a mile ; the water upon it is visibly discoloured.

Turt/e’s Harbour, or Barrueco de Tortugas, on the coast of Brazil, in S. America, is 60 leagues at E. S. E. from the point or cape of Arbrafec, or Des Arbres Sec, and the shore is flat all the way from the gulf of Maranhao.
an island so named from the great number of turtle found near it, is near the N. W. part of the island of St. Domingo. See T ortne.
or Sal Tortuga , is near the W„ end of New-Andalutia and Terra Firma. It is uninhabited, although G G g

about 30 miles in circumference, and abounding with salt. N. lat. 11 36, W. long. 65. It is 14 leagues to the west of Margaritta Island, and 17 or 18 from Cape Blanco on the main. There are many islands of this name on the north coast of South-America.

Tot tit, on the coast of Chili, and in the South Pacific Ocean, is the south point of the port of Coquimbo, and 7 or 8 leagues from the Fajaros Islands- 1 ortegas road is round the point of the fame name, where ships may ride in from 6 to 10 fathoms, over a bottom of black sand, near a rock called the Tortugas. The road is well sheltered, but will not contain above 20 or 50 ships safely. Ships not more than 200 tons burden may careen on the Tortugas rock.
Creek, a north head water of Alleghany river, whole mouth is east of Squeaughta Creek, and 17 miles north-westerly of the IchuaToaun ¡ which fee.
a place or village at the Great Falls in Paliaik river, New-Jerfey.

a river which empties through the south-eastern bank of the Ohio, and is navigable with batteaux to the Occafioto Mountains. It is á long river, and has few branches, and interlocks with Red Creek, 01 Clinches river, a bfanch of the Tennessee. It has below the mountains, especially for 15 miles from its mouth, very good land.
a township of New-York, in Ontario co. In 1796, 93 of the inhabitants were electors.
TowtRHiLL, a village in the township of South-Kingstowr, Rhode-Ifiand, where a post-office is kept, it is 10 miles west of Newport, and 282 from Philadelphia.
a township of Windham co. Vermont, west of Westminster and Putney, containing 676 inhabitants.
0, a township of Middlesex co. Massachusetts, containing 993 inhabitants. Itwag incorporated in 1732, and lies' 45 m ies northward of Boston.
Tow N su E a harbour on the coast of the District of Maine, where is a bold harbour, having 9 fathoms water, sheltered from all winds. High w ater, at full and change, 43 minutes after 10 o'clock.
now Car let on, a settlement on the northern side of Cha lent Bay, about j leagues from the great river
er Casquipibiac, in a south-west direction. It is a place of considerable trade io cod-filh, &c.
a place in Sussex co. New-Jerfey, 8 miles southerly of Newtown.
a village in Talbot co. Maryland ; about 6 miles S. E. of Oxford.

The, a village of Pennsylvania, in Montgomery co. having about a dozen houses, and a German Lutheran and Calvinist church united. It is 9 miles from Morristown, n from Pottfgrove, and 36 from Philadelphia.
a village of Maryland, in Somerset co. situated at the head of Wicomico Creek, a branch of the river Wicomico, 7 miles south-west of Salisbury, and 6 north of Princess Ann.
a village of Maryland, in Frederick co. situated on Cotoctin Creek, between the South and Cotoctin Mountains, and 7 miles south-westerly ©f Fredericktown.
Bay, Great , lies on the N. E. comer ot Lake Michigan. It has a narrow entrance, and sets up into the land south-eastward, and receives Traverse river from the E.
Creek, a small branch ©f Choptank river.
Islands-, form a part of Mr.Shortland , sA>w-dfor£¿z,(Surville , s Archipelago of the Arlacides) lying from 638 to 7 30 S- lat. and from 155 34 to 156 E. long, from Greenwich. See Arsacides , See.
River ,a small river ©f the island of St. John’s, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. It empties into the fca 3 or 4 leagues to the westward of the eastern extremity of die island.
a township in Grafton co. New-Hampihire, incorporated in 1769.
a final! river of N. Carolina, which falls into Neus river,at Newbern. It is navigable for sea vessels, 13 miles above the town, and for boats 30. See Neus.

is one of the largest towns in New-Jeiiey, and the metropolis of the State, situated in Hunterdon co. on the E. fide of Delaware river, opposite the falls, and nearly in the centre of the State from N. to S. The river is not navigable above these falls, except for boats which will carry from 500 to 500 bushels of wheat.. This town, with áambertun, which joins it on the south,

contains between aoo and 300 house?» and about 3,000 inhabitants. Here the legislature statedly meets, the supreme court fits, and most of the public offices are kept. The inhabitants have lately erected a handsome court-house, 100 feet by 30, with a semi-hexagon at each end, over which is a balustrade. Here are also a church for Episcopalians, one for Presbyterians,one for Methodists, and a Quaker meeting-house. In-the neighbourhood of this pleasant town, are a great many gentlemen’s feats, finely situated on the banks of the Delaware, and ornamented with taste and elegance. Here is a flourishing academy. It is 13 miles 8. W. of Princeton, 30 from Brunswick, and 30 N. E. of Philadelphia. N.lat. 40 15, W. long. 74 15.

a small post-town of the District of Maine, Hancock co. 13 miles, W. by S. of Sullivan, 31 N. E. by E. of Penobscot, 386 N. E. of Boston, and 633 N. E. of Philadelphia. This town is near Desert Island; and in a part of it called The Narrow were about 4® families in 1796.
the chief town of Jones* county, N. Carolina, situated on the 8. side of Trent river. It contains but few houses, besides the court-house and gaol. It is j 31 miles from Philadelphia,

Bay, or Trejpajses Bay, and Harbour, on the south side of Newfoundland Island, near the 8. E. part, and about 31 miles to the N. westward of Cape Race, the 8. E. point of the island. The harbour is large, well secured, and the ground good to anchor in.
IJland, a small island, one of the Bahamas. N. lat. 30 51, W. long. 69 53.
Skoals, lie to the westward of the peninsula of Yucatan, near the E. shore of the Bay of Campeachy, nearly W. of Cape Condecedo- N. lat. 17 3, W. long, in 59.
Bay , on the coast of Terra Firma, is nearly due south from Bonair Island, one of the Little Antilles, to the east of Curassou Island.

IJland, a small island at the bottom of the Gulf of Campeachy, westward of Port-Royal Island, about 3 leagues from E. to W. The creek which separates it from Port-Royal Island is scarcely broad enough to admit a-canoe. Good fresh water will be got by digging 5 or 6 feet deep in the salt send ; a less depth it is brack
iíh and salt, and at a greater depth than 6 feet it is salt again.
a small island in the 8 . Atlantic Ocean, due E. off Spiritu Santo, in Brazil. S. lat. 20 30, W. long. 41 ro. It is also called Trinity.

or Trini dada I/land, near the coats of Terra Firma, at the north part of 8. America. It partly forms the Gulf of Paria, or Bocea del Drago,, and is much larger than any other upon the coaft. It is 36 leagues in length, and 18 or 20 in breadth, but the climate is rather unhealthy, and little of it is cleared. The current sets so strong along the coaft from E. to W. as to render moil of its bays and harbours useless. It produces sugar, fine tobacco, indigo, ginger, a variety of fruit, some cotton, and Indian corn. It was taken by Sir Walter Raleigh, in 1595, and by the French in 1676, who plundered the island, and extorted money from the inhabitants. It was captured by the British in February, 1797. It is situated between 59 and 62 W. long, and in 10 N. lat. The N. E. point lies in lat. 10 28 N._ and long. 59 37 W. The chief town is St. Joseph.

a town of Mexico, in the province of Guatimala, on the banks of the river Belen, 12 miles from the sea; but the road is almoft impassable by land. It is 70 miles S. E. of Guatimala, and 24 eaft of La Conception. N. lat. 13, W. long. 91 40.
on the north coaft of the Ifthmus of Darien, lies eastward of Bocea del Toro, and some clusters of small islands, and S. W. of Porto Bello and Fort Chagre. N. lat. 8 30, W. long. 81 30.

or La Consonase Port, a town on a bay of the Pacific Ocean, about 65 miles 8. E. of P etapa, and 162 from the town of Guatimala. All the goods that are sent from Peru and Mexico to Acaxatla, about 12 miles from it, are brought to this port. It is 9 miles from the town to the harbour which is much frequented, and isa place of great trade ; being the nearest landing to Guatimala for ships that come from Peru, Panama, and Mexico.
one of the sea-ports on the south part of the island of Cuba, in the Weft-Indies; situated N. W. from the weft end of the groupe of islands called Jardín de la Reyna. N. Lit. si 40, W. long. 80 30.
an open town of Veragua, and audience of Mexico, in N. America.
Channel, has the island of Tobago on the N. W. and that of Trinidad on the south.
or Trinity, a town of New-Granada,.and Terra Firma, in 8. America, about 23 miles N. E. of St. Fe.
Bay, on the eaft fide of Newfoundland island., between lat. 47 53 30, and 48 37 N.
Port, a large bay of Martinico Island,in the Weft-Indies, formed on the south-east by Point Caravelle.
lj]e lies near the coaft of Patagonia, in 8. America, eastward of York Islands. 8. lat. 30 37.
I/le, the north-eaftertrmoft of the small islands on the south-east coaft of the peninsula of Alaska, on the N. W. coast of N. America, N. E. of Foggy Islands.
a cape on the coaft bf Brazil, S- America,
a bay on the north coaft of S. America, is W. 8. W. of the river Turiano. It has good anchorage and is well sheltered from the swell of the sea.
Bay, in the Gulf of Honduras, or south shore of the Gulf of Mexico, is within tire Island of Pines. Dulce river lies a little to the weft.
a small island on the N. coast of the Island of St. John’s, lying off the mouth of Shimene Port, and in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

Txois Rivieres, a bay at the eaft end of the above-mentioned Island of St. John’s, and weft of Cape Breton Island. Three streams fall into it from different directions ; hence its name. N. lat. 46 5, W. long. 62 1$.

Rivieres , or the Three Rivers, or Treble River, a town of Lower Canada, fettled by the French in 1610 ; ánd is ib called from the junction of three waters a little below the town where they fall into the river St. Lawrence. The town stands on the northern bank of the St. Lawrence, at that part of the river called Lake St. Pierre. It is but thinly inhabited ; is commodioufly situated for the fur trade, and was formerly the feat of the French government, and the grand mart to which the natives resorted. It is pleasantly situated in a fertile country, about 50 miles south-weft j of (Quebec. The inhabitants are mostly rich,
rich, and have elegant, well furnished houses, and the country round wears a fine appearance. N. lat. 46 51, W. long. 75 15.
TiioMPtAUR, Cape, del Enganna, or False Cape , is the easternmost point, of the island of St. Domingo. N. lat. 18 25, W. long, from Paris 71.

Keys, are small islands or rocks, on tire north of Crab Island, and off the east coast of Porto Rico Island. A number of tropic birds breed here, which are a species never seen but between the tropics.
quo a bay at the southern extremity of the eastern part of Lake Huron, separated from Matchudoch Bay on the N. E. by a broad promontory.
TRoququA, an island on the north coast of S. America, in the mouth of a small bay near Cape Seco, a short way S. E. from the east point of the bay or river Taratura.
on the south side of the island of St. Domingo. From this to Cape Reate, or Cape a Foux, the lhore is rocky,
a settlement in the northern part of the French division of the island of St. Domingo. It is leagues E. of Ouanaminthe, and 2 S. E. of Limonado. N. lat. 19 3j, W. long, from Paris 74 rr.

a post-town of New-York, Rensselaer co. 6 miles north of Albany, 3 S. of Laniingburg city, and 271 from Philadelphia. The township of Troy is bounded E. by Petersburg, and was taken from Kenssellaerwyck township, and incorporated in 1791. In 1796, 550 of the inhabitants were electors. Seven years ago, the fcite of the flourishing village of Troy was covered with flocks and herds, and the spot on which a school, containing 160 scholars, is now erected, was then probably a sheepfold. The school is under the direction of 3 schoolmasters, and is a very promising seminary.

a town of Nova-Scotia, situated in Halifax co. at the head of the Basin of Minas, opposite to, and 3 miles southerly of. Onflow ; 40 miles N. by W. of Halifax, and 40 from Pictou. It was settled by the North-Irifh, some Scotch, and the descendants of NorthInfh. Through this town runs the river called by the Indians Shubbenacadie, navigable for boats to within 9 miles of Fort Sackville.

a township of Massachusetts* situated in Barnstable county, lies between lat. 41 57, and 42 4 N. and between long. 70 4 and 70 13 W. It is on the easternmost part of the peninsula of Cape Cod, 5 7 miles 8. E. of Boston, in a straight line, but as the road runs it is 112, and 40 from the court-house of Barnstable. It is the Pamet of the Indians, and after its settlement in 1700 was some time called Dangerfield; it y/as incorporated under its prelent name in 1709, and contains 1,193 inhabitants. Only one family of Indians remained a few years since, and lived on Pamet Point. In the valley called Great-Hotlo<w, a creek sets up from the bay, at the mouth of which is a tide harbour. The other landing-places are of small note. Pamet Harbour is about 100 yards wide at the mouth, but is wider within; and if repaired would be of public utility. It lies above 3 leagues S. E. of Cape-Cod harbour. The hill on which the meeting-house stands branches from the high land of CapeCod, well known to seamen. The mountain of clay in Truro, in the midst of sandy hills, seems to have been placed there by the God of Nature, to serve as a foundation for a light-house, which if erected might save the lives of thousands, and millions of property. The foil of 1 riiro is, in molt places, sandy, like Provmcetuwn ; and the in, habitants derive their principal subsistence from the sea, which here abounds with vast variety of iilh. Great part of their corn and vegetables are procured from Boston and the neighbouring towns. 1 wo inhabitants of 1 ruro, Captains David Smith and Gamaliel Callings, were the first who adventured to Falkland Islands in pursuit of whales. This voyage, which was crowned with success, was undertaken in 1774, by the advice of Admiral Montague of the British navy. The whalemen of Truro now visit the coast of Guinea and Brazil. Many of the masters of ships employed from Boston and other ports, are natives of Truro. The elderly men and small boys remain at home to culti. vate the ground; the rest are at sea fds of the year. The women are generally employed in spinning, weaving knitting, &c.
a bay, harbour, and town, at the bottom of St, Giles’s Bay, on the coast of Honduras, in the gulf of that

that name. The bay is about 6 miles broad, being deep and secure, and defended by a castle ; but it has little trade. The town stands about a league from the North Sea, between two rivers, the mouths of which, with some islands before them, form the harbour. The country is exceedingly fruitful in corn and grapes, and notwithstanding the heat of the climate, very populous. The city is defended by a thick wall towards the sea, and is inaccessible but by a narrow, fteep ascent. The castle joins to the wall, and stands on a hill. Behind the city are high mountains. It lies 300 miles N. E. of Amapalla. N. lat. 15 30, W. long. 8j 56.
f RuxiLLo, the first diocese in the audience of Lima, in Peru.

a bay or harbour, and one of the principal cities of the province of the fame name in Peru, is 11 leagues from Chocope, and 80 N. \V. of Lima ; and according to Ulloa, the city lies in lat. 8 6 3 S. and long. 77 30 W. It stands in the valley of Chimo, on a small river, about half a league from the sea ; is surrounded with a brick wall, and from its circuit may be classed among cities of the third order. Two leagues to the northward is the port of Guanchaco, the channel of its trade. The houses make an elegant appearance, being generally of brick, with stately balconies and superb porticos.

or Nojira Senior a de la Paz , a town of New-Granada (Venezuela) and Terra Firma, in 8. America, 125 miles south of Maracaibo Lake ; on the southernmost bank of which lake is a village, called Truxillo, dependent on this city. The city is in lat. 9 21 N. and long. 69 W.
Mountains , in N. Carolina, lie N. W. of the town of Salisbury, on the borders of the State of Tennessee.
Tu the chief town of the division of Señora, in New-Mexico.
a small island, one of the Society I stands, in the 8. Pacific Ocean, is about 4 or 5 leagues to the N. by W. or N. N. W. from Bolabola. S. lat. 16 12, W. long. 151 44.
I" u c p E i, on the coast of Chili, and the W. fide of 8. America, is on the 8. Atlantic Ocean, 10 leagues N. N. E. from Rio Imperial, and 10 to the island of Santa Maria, or St. Mary.
a town of the Creek nation of Indians.
Creek, in Maryland, Tal. bot co. a branch of Choptank river.
the port of entry for the district of Little Egg Hai bour, in the State of New-Jerfey.

a province of 8. America, so called from a tribe of Indians, and in the 8. W. division of Paraguay. It is bounded N. partly by Lus Chicas, in Peru, and partly by Chaco ; 8. by Cayo and Pampas ; E. by Paraguay Proper, and Rio" de la Plata ; and W. by St. Jago, in Chili, and the t>. end of Chicas ; extending itself from Rio Vermejo to Rio Quarto, almost from lat. 24 to 34 south, and from E. to W. where broadest, from the river Salado to the ridge of the Cordillera, separating it from Chili, almost from long. 6» to 69 30 W. The climate is healthy and temperate. The lands are rich and well cultivated, especially towards Chili, with some defart cantons towards the Magellanic fide. Its two principal rivers are Dolce and Salado, that is, the sweet and salt ones ; besides innumerable smaller streams. The natives are somewhat civilized by the Spaniards, and cover themselves with their woollen and cotton manufactures, and live in villages.

a town of New-Granada, and Terra Firma, in N. America. It stands in a valley of the fame name, every where surrounded by mountains. The air is very healthy, and the foil fruitful, and a river divides the place. It is 200 miles S. of Maracaibo city. N. lat. 7 10, W. long. 68 36.
a town of New. Hampshire, in Stratford co. situated on the N. E. fide of Lake Winipifeogee, adjoining Wolf borough, containing 109 inhabitants.

River, in Georgia, is the main branch of Savannah river. The other great branch is Keowee, which joining with the other, 15 miles N. W. of the northern boundary of Wilke's co. form the Savannah. Some branches of the Tugelo rife in the State of Tennessee. A respectable traveller relates that in ten minutes, having walked his hoife moderately, he tasted of Tugelo, Apalachicola, and Hiwaffee rivers.
Creek, in the State of New-York, is 16 miles above Schenectady. E. of the creek is a curious Indian inscription.
ships of Onondago co. New-York, having Sempronius on the well, and Fabius on the eaft. It is within the jurisdiction of Pompey, and lies ry miles S. E. of the ferry on Cayuga Lake.

an Indian town situated on the Chata Uche river. It is situated, according to Bar tram, on a vaft plain, and is the largest, most compact, and belt situated Indian town he ever saw. The habitations are large, and neatly built; the walls of the houses are constructed of a wooden frame, then lathed and plaiftered inside and out with a reddish well tempered clay or mortar, which gives them the appearance of red brick walls ; and the roofs are neatly covered with cypress bark, or shingles. The town appears populous ana thriving, full of youth and young children ; and is supposed to contain about inhabitants. They are able to mufter jee gun-men or warriors. Their national language is radically different from the Creek or Mufcogulge tongue, and is called the Savanna or Savanuca tongue. It is said to be the fame or a dialect of the Shavvanefe. Although in confederacy with the Creeks, they do not mix with them ; and are of importance enough to excite the jealousy of the whole Mufcogulge confederacy, and are usually at variance, yet are wife enough to unite against a common enemv to support the interest of the general Creek confederacy.

UNITED STATES. The United States of America occupy, perhaps, the 39th part of the habitable globe, and the 199th part of the whole. They are c lasted in 3 grand divisions.
I. The N E w - É sc or
N E w-H AWSHfife, including the and

These grand divisions, as also the differ-» ent States, have been already described ; to which we refer the reader. The territory of the United States is in length 1,250 miles, and in breadth 1040, lying between 31 and 46 N. lat. and between 64 and 96 W. long, from London j bounded north and east by British America, or the provinces of Upper and Lower Canada, and New-Brunfwick; south-east by the Atlantic Ocean ; south by East and West Florida, and west by the river Misiifippi. According to Mr. Hutchins, it contains, by computation# a million of square miles, in which are

Acres of land in the United States The largest livers that border upon, or pass through the United States, are Mit íiíippi, Ohio, and Tennessee, on the west side of the Alleghany Mountains; and the Alatamaha, Savannah, Santee, Cape Fear, Roanoke, James, Patowmac, Suss quehannah, Delaware, Hudson, Connecticut, Merrimack, Pilcataqua, Androscoggin, Kennebeck, and Penobscot,' whose general courses are from northwest and north, to S. E. and south, and which empty into the Atlantic Ocean. The United States embosom some of the largest lakes in the world. The most remarkable lie in a chain along their northern boundary upon the Canada line, and are lakes Superior, Michigan# Huron, Erie, Ontario, Champlain e, George, Memphrcmagog, Wmipifcogee, and Umbagog. The most remarkable swamps aie Ouaquaphenogaw, or Eknanfanoka, nearly 300 miles in circumference.in the State of Georgia ; the two Dismals in North-Caroiina, of immense extent, each containing a large lake in its centre ; and Buffalos Swamp, in the north-western parts of Pennsylvania. The principal mountains in the United States arc Agamenticus, in Maine ; the White Mountains and Mori adnock, in New-Hampihire ; Wachuseisin Massachusetts ; the Green Mountains,

tains, in Vermont; and the Alleghany Mountains, about 900 miles in length, and from 150 to 250 in breadth. The face of the country, generally speaking, is agreeably variegated with plains and mountains, vales and hills. New-England is an uneven, hilly and rocky country. A brdad space, including all the branches of the Alleghany Mountains, commencing at Hudson's river in NewYork, and extending circuitously southwesterly through all the States westward and southward, Delaware excepted, is mountainous. Eastward of these mountains, quite to the fea-coalt, a border of from 60 to 100 miles, and sometimes more, in breadth, is a remarkably level country, and in the southern States free of itone. Weft of this range of mountains, is a fine, and charmingly diversified country, well watered', fertile,, temperate, and increasing in population with unexampled rapidity. Every species of foil that the earth affords may be found in the United States ; and all the various kinds of fruits, grain, pulse, and garden plants and roots which are found in Europe; besides a great variety of native vegetable productions. Tobacco, rice, indigo, wheat, corn, cotton, rye, oats, barley, buck-wheat, flax, and hemp, are among the principal prodho tions of the United States, The United States conftitute what may, with strict propriety, be called a It consists of 16 separate, independent States, having governors, constitutions and aws of their own, united under a j general, federal constitution of government, administered by an elective head, and by a proportionate number of representatives of the people from all the States. The merchants cf this country carry on an extensive foreign trade with Russia, Sweden, Denmark, Hamburgh, United Netherlands, Great-Britain, j Austrian Netherlands and Germany, France, Spain, Portugal, and Italy, in Europe —with Morocco, and several other parts of Africa—with China, and various Asiatic countries, and the EastIndia Islands—with the West-Indies, and the N. W. coast of N. America. The principal articles exported are fish, lumber, live stock, beef, pork, flour, wheat, Indian corn, tobacco, rice, indigo, flax-seed, pot and pearl ashes, iron, &c. The exports of the year ending Sept. 30, 1796, amounted to 67,064,097 dollars. Six years before, the value of

exports was but about 18 millions oí dollars. The tea imported into the .United States in 1791, directly from ' China, was 2,601,852 lbs. and the prices in Philadelphia 33 per cent, lowes than in London, the drawback deducted. The export of salted beef and pork, in 1791, war 66,000 barrels. The ¿firing trade 0: u'.c United States is rendered peculiarly important as a means of defence or of annoying the commerce of hostile nations, from the circumstance that the Republic has not yet adopted a naval establishment. The filhermen, while that continues to be the cale, may be transmuted by war immediately into a corps of privateersmen, and their ships into private vessels of war ; because the navy of any hostile nation will suspend the fisheries, as long as the; e is no naval force to oppose them. The amazing importance of the fisheries to the United States is evident from an inspection of the records of only the two counties of Suffolk and Essex, which, comprise the sea-ports of Boston, Salem, Marblehead, Beverly, Ipswich, Newbury-Port, Gloucester, and Haverhill. It appears that there were taken, brought in, and libelled, in the maritime court of these two-counties, during the late war, 1,095 vessels with their cargoes; and 13 cargoes taken from such ihips as had been abandoned after capture making in the whole 1108. It has been stated by a British premier, in the British House of Commons, that the number of vesselsj belonging to Great-Britain in 1774, was 6,219 fail; of which, 3,908 were British built, and 2,311 American built. Thus above a sixth part of all their vest, fels were brought in as prizes by them into the ports of the United States, with cargoes of great value, composed of every species of military and domestic supi ply, in a season of the utmost emergency. It is likewise conjectured by well informed persons that 55 per cent, of all the captures was made by the people of Massachusetts. The capital portsfor large ships, in the United States stand thus ranked, Newport, in RhodeIfland ; Portland, in the District of Maine; and New-York. Several important branches of manufactures have grown up and flourished with a rapidity which surprises ; affording an encouraging assurance of success in future attempts. Of these the following are the most considerable, viz. oí Skim — tanned and

and tawed leathers, dressed skins, slices, boots, and flippers, harness and saddlery of all kinds, portmanteaus and trunks, leather breeches, gloves, muffs and tippets, parchment and glue. Of Iron — bar and sheet iron, steel, nail rods, and nails, implements of husbandry, stoves, pots, and other household utensils, the steel and iron work of carriages and for ship-building, anchors, scale-beams and weights, and various tools of artificers ; arms of all kinds. Of Wood —ships, cabinet wares, and turnery, wool and cotton cards, and other machinery for manufactures and husbandry, mathematical instruments, coopers’ wares of every kind. Of Flax and Hemp —cables, sail-cloth, cordage, twine and packthread. Of Clay —bricks and coarse tiles, and .potters’ wares. Ardent spirits and malt liquors. Writing and printing paper, sheathing and wrapping paper, pasteboards, fullers’ or press papers, and paper hangings. Books. Hatts of fur and wool, and mixtures of both. Women’s stuff and Aik shoes. Refined sugars. Chocolate. Oil of animals and feeds. Soap, spermaceti and tallow candles; copper and brass wares; particularly utensils for distillers, fugar refiners, and brewersandirons and other .articles for household use; clocks, philosophical apparatus; tin wares of almost all kinds for ordinary use ; carriages of all kinds; snuff, fmoaking and chewing tobacco ; starch, and hair-powder ; lampblack, and oth^r painters’ colours; printers’ ink, magnesia, gunpowder. Besides the manufactures of these articles, which are carried on as regular trades, and have attained to a considerable degree of maturity, there is a vast scene of household manufacturing, which contributes -very largely to the supply of the community. Religion here, is placed on its proper basis, without the feeble and unwarranted aid of the civil power, and is left to be supported by its own evidence, by the lives of its professors, and by the almighty care of its Divine Author. The loUov/ing denominations of Christians are more or less numerous, viz. Congregationalists, Presbyterians, Episcopalians, Dutch Reformed Church., Baptists, Quakers, Methodists, Roman Catholics, German Lutherans, German Calvinists, Moravians or United Brethren of the Episcopal church, Tankers, Siennonists, Univetfalists, and Shakers.

There are a few Jews ; and many who reject revealed religion as unnecessary* inconvenient, and fabulous, and plead the sufficiency of natural religion. In 1790, there were about 3,930,000 inhabitants in the United States; 697,697 of whom were slaves. The present number is probably above four millions and a half, made up of almost all the different nations of Europe, but principally of the descendants of the English nation. The military strength of this country lies in a well disciplined militia of about 900,000 brave and independent freemen, and an army of about 3 or

4,000 men to defend the frontiers of the Union, and to man the several fortresses in the different parts of the Un:ted States. The sum voted by Congress to support the naval and military establishment of the-United States for 1796 was 1,818,873 dollars. The civil list is about 300,000 dollars annually. .See America, Xortb-America, &c.

or Torktonun, a port of entry and poft-town us Virginia, and capital of York co. Bay is 9 miles long, and 4 broad, and spreads to the southward before the city of New-York. It is l'ormed by the confluence of Eaft and Hudson’s rivers, and embosoms several small islands, of which* Governor’s Island is the principal» It communicates with the ocean through the Narrows, between Staten and Long Islands, which are scarcely 2 miles wide. The passage up to New-York, from Sandy Hook, the point of sand that extends furthest into the sea, is safe, and not above 20 miles in length. The common navigation is between the eaft and weft banks, in about 22 feet water. The 'lighthouse at Sandy Hook is in lat. 40 30 N. and long. 74 2 W.
